results.title: The Emancipation of women: 1890-1930
results.brief_description: Compilation of archival film showing early campaigns for women’s rights, and the rights and freedoms won by the end of the 1920’s. This film captures the Suffragette movement in its campaign to earn the vote. The historical advisor for this film was Arthur Marwick, Professor of History, The Open University.

results.title: Elephant baby
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: This film tells the story of a baby elephant from its first day in the jungle, through many weeks of training, to the day it joins a working force of elephants in a lumber camp. Photographed in Mysore, India, the film gives an account of the daily activities of working elephants and of the people who train them, including the shooting of a tiger which came too close to the camp for comfort.

results.title: The Elephant
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Nature of things”.
Jiminy Cricket tells the history of the evolution of the elephant, from prehistoric mastodons and mammoths; describes the elephant of today and how it uses its trunk; and shows how the Indian mahout trains his elephant to work.

results.title: Elements of survival. Part 1. Populations
results.creator_credit: Doug Lower and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: First of a two-part series this episode focuses on the population spiral and looks at mankind from pre-history to the present explosion with its doubling of world population about every 35 years. The film looks at the possible consequences of unchecked growth, and the wide gulf between the haves and the have-nots.

results.title: The Electron's tale
results.creator_credit: Bob Godfrey, Peter Green, Beryl Stevens, Film Producers Guild and W.M. Larkins Studio
results.brief_description: Made to mark Mullard’s 50th anniversary. In a light-hearted vein, this film describes the development of electronics from the electron’s point of view. Live action scenes supplement the cartoon sequences unobtrusively to bring home the importance of the role played by electrons in our lives.

results.title: Electromagnetic waves
results.brief_description: Part of the Physical Science Study Committee series. Shows why we believe in the unity of the electro-magnetic radiation spectrum. Experiment shows that the radiation arises from accelerated charge and consists of transverse waves that can be polarised. Interference (Young’s double slit experiment) is shown in four different regions of electromagnetic spectrum: X-ray, visible light, microwave and radiowave.

results.title: Electrochemistry
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Diagrams and a simple bench experiment demonstrate theory and practice of electro-plating. Industrial applications of electro-chemistry in copper refining, the reduction of alumina to metallic aluminium and the plating and surface treatment of metal parts are illustrated. Deals also with the electro-chemical action in batteries and accumulators.

results.title: Electric furnaces
results.creator_credit: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare, British Iron and Steel Federation and Merton Park
results.brief_description: Steels for certain special purposes are made in furnaces heated by electricity. This film explains the construction and working of the electric arc and high frequency induction furnaces. Animated diagrams are used to illustrate the chemical reactions in the arc furnace and the principles of induction heating.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Durst, Frank A. Hoare, British Iron and Steel Federation and Merton Park
